title: Question 126

children: A 65-year-old woman is evaluated for a mole beneath the right eye that has been present for several months but appears to be growing.

shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Nodular basal cell carcinoma typically presents as a pearly or translucent nodule or papule with arborizing telangiectasias and may have a central depression or ulceration with a rolled waxy border.
A small portion of basal cell carcinomas contain pigment and can mimic a malignant melanoma; biopsy is often needed to confirm the diagnosis.
The most likely diagnosis is pigmented basal cell carcinoma (BCC) (
Option B

). Nodular BCC typically presents as a pearly or translucent nodule or papule with arborizing telangiectasias. It may have a central depression or ulceration with a rolled waxy border. About 6% of BCCs are pigmented, such as this one, which has dark brown pigment along the superior border of the tumor and a dot of pigment located at the middle of the inferior border. Pigmented BCCs are more common in patients with darker skin. Pigmented BCCs are a low-risk BCC subtype. However, they can mimic malignant melanoma, and biopsy is necessary to differentiate them. Although they have low mortality, significant local tissue destruction can occur if not treated. Mohs micrographic surgery is a surgical technique that enhances the ability to leave surgical margins free of tumor and at the same time minimize the resection of normal tissue. Compared with standard excision, Mohs micrographic surgery is associated with a reduced rate of tumor recurrence. Mohs micrographic surgery is usually reserved for skin cancers that have a high risk for recurrence or for tumors located in areas where minimal destruction of tissue is of cosmetic or functional importance. For the lesion on this patient's face near the eye, Mohs micrographic surgery would be recommended for the best chance of complete tumor eradication and cosmetic outcomes.
Because of the asymmetry and color variation of this patient's lesion, malignant melanoma (
Option A

) could be considered in the differential diagnosis. However, the rolled borders of this patient's lesion and pearly translucent nature of the tumor are features of BCC and stand in contrast to the berry-like appearance of nodular melanoma (as

Biopsy should be performed to confirm the diagnosis. The most likely diagnosis in this patient, however, is a pigmented BCC.
Seborrheic keratosis (
Option C

) is a benign skin growth, often on the trunk in older adults. It is usually hyperpigmented from brown to black in color. Unlike this patient's lesion, seborrheic keratosis presents as a well-circumscribed, keratotic, “stuck-on” papule.
Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) (
Option D

) of the skin is the second most common skin cancer. SCC typically presents as hyperkeratotic, indurated papules or plaques in sun-exposed areas. SCC does not typically have pigmentation or the rolled borders seen in this patient's lesion.

references: Kim DP, Kus KJ, Ruiz E. Basal cell carcinoma review. Hematol Oncol Clin North Am. 2019;33:13-24.
